articles.headline: U.S. Finds Pervasive Bias Against Latinos by Arizona Sheriff
articles.snippet: An investigation that lasted more than two years singled out Sheriff Joe Arpaio as helping to nurture his department’s “culture of bias.”
articles.abstract: An investigation that lasted more than two years singled out Sheriff Joe Arpaio as helping to nurture his department’s “culture of bias.”
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In a strongly worded critique of the country’s best-known sheriff, the Justice Department on Thursday accused Sheriff Joe Arpaio of engaging in “unconstitutional policing” by unfairly targeting Latinos for detention and arrest and retaliating against those who complain.

articles.headline: U.S. Marks End to 9-Year War, Leaving an Uncertain Iraq
articles.snippet: Officials conducted a modest ceremony in Baghdad days before the last troops’ exit, which will end the United States’ most ambitious and bloodiest military campaign since Vietnam.
articles.abstract: Officials conducted a modest ceremony in Baghdad days before the last troops’ exit, which will end the United States’ most ambitious and bloodiest military campaign since Vietnam.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — At a crowded market in the city center here, the flotsam of the war is for sale. Ripped Fuel workout supplement. Ready-to-eat meals, macaroni and cheese “Mexican style.” Pistol holsters. Nothing seems off limits to the merchants out for a quick dinar, not even a bottle of prescription pills from a pharmacy in Waco, Tex., probably tossed out by a departing soldier.

articles.headline: Questioning The Benefit Of Curbing Short Sales
articles.snippet: Complaints from companies have led to curbs on short-selling in both the United States and Europe, but evidence is lacking that the practice is harmful to the market — and it may help investors.
articles.abstract: Complaints from companies have led to curbs on short-selling in both the United States and Europe, but evidence is lacking that the practice is harmful to the market — and it may help investors.

articles.headline: Kinder’s Major Bet on a Boom in Fracking
articles.snippet: Kinder Morgan, the pipeline company, hopes its $21 billion acquisition of the El Paso Corporation will help it capitalize on once-in-a-generation boom in oil and gas drilling.
articles.abstract: Kinder Morgan, the pipeline company, hopes its $21 billion acquisition of the El Paso Corporation will help it capitalize on once-in-a-generation boom in oil and gas drilling.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The oil and gas business is full of gamblers who drill deep and often, praying for gushers but frequently ending up with dry holes.

articles.headline: Times Chief Is to Retire at Year-End
articles.snippet: Janet L. Robinson, who served as chief executive of The New York Times Company during a time of rapid change and uncertainty in the newspaper industry, will step down this month.
articles.abstract: Janet L. Robinson, who served as chief executive of The New York Times Company during a time of rapid change and uncertainty in the newspaper industry, will step down this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Janet L. Robinson, who served as chief executive of The New York Times Company during a time of rapid change and uncertainty in the newspaper industry, will step down at the end of the month, the company announced Thursday.

articles.headline: The Race to Greener Bottles Could Be Long
articles.snippet: Despite dueling announcements claiming technological breakthroughs in all-plant bottles, neither Coke nor Pepsi is confident enough in the technology to offer a firm timetable.
articles.abstract: Despite dueling announcements claiming technological breakthroughs in all-plant bottles, neither Coke nor Pepsi is confident enough in the technology to offer a firm timetable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over their decades of competition, the battle between Coca-Cola and PepsiCo has taken on many colors — brown (cola), orange (juice), blue (sport drinks) and clear (water).

articles.headline: As Sales Lag, Stores Shuffle the Calendar
articles.snippet: The Saturday before Christmas is too crucial to retailers to be left in the hands of procrastinating shoppers, so many stores are having “Super Saturday” this weekend instead.
articles.abstract: The Saturday before Christmas is too crucial to retailers to be left in the hands of procrastinating shoppers, so many stores are having “Super Saturday” this weekend instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: When is the final Saturday before Christmas? Don’t bother consulting a calendar if you’re shopping at Macy’s, Sears or J. C. Penney.

articles.headline: As Romney Steps Cautiously, Gingrich Duels With Others
articles.snippet: The seven Republican contenders met in Sioux City to spar with one another, and to critique President Obama.
articles.abstract: The seven Republican contenders met in Sioux City to spar with one another, and to critique President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — The leading Republican presidential candidates largely shelved their contentious attacks on one another to deliver their closing arguments on Thursday night at the final debate before the nominating contests begin, but Newt Gingrich did not escape sharp questions about his record in and out of government and his ability to defeat President Obama.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Gingrich Push on Health Care Appears at Odds With G.O.P.
articles.snippet: As a candidate for president, Newt Gingrich is criticizing some of the same health care programs that he supported as a consultant.
articles.abstract: As a candidate for president, Newt Gingrich is criticizing some of the same health care programs that he supported as a consultant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly before the passage of President Obama’s stimulus bill in 2009, Newt Gingrich’s political committee put out a video of Mr. Gingrich denouncing it as a “big politician, big bureaucracy, pork-laden bill.”
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Mike McIntire
